links.*: A Closed Letter to Andrea Charicoryides Surnamed Polygrapheus, Logothete of the Theme of Geodesia in the Empire, Bard of the Court of Camelot, Malleus Malitiarium, Inclinga Sum Sometimes Known as Charles Williams
A Fragment of an Epic: Before Jerusalem Richard Makes an End of Speech
Adventures in Unnatural History and Medieval Metres, being the Freaks of Fisiologus
Bilbo's Last Song (at the Grey Havens)
Chip the glasses and crack the plates!
Cold be hand and heart and bone,
Dark Are the Clouds about the North
Far over the misty mountains cold
Farewell We Call to Hearth and Hall!
From dark Dunharrow in the dim morning
Hey dol! merry dol! ring a dong dillo!
Hop along, my little friends, up the Withywindle!
I Sit beside the Fire and Think
Lemminkainen Goeth to the Fords of Oxen
Over Old Hills and Far Away
Over the land there lies a long shadow
Poems in The Lord of the Rings
Seek for the Sword that was broken
Sir Gawain and the Green Knight
Song of the Ent and Entwife
Song of the Mounds of Mundburg
Tha Eadigan Saelidan: The Happy Mariners
The Battle of the Eastern Field

The Complaint of Mîm the Dwarf
The Homecoming of Beorhtnoth Beorhthelm's Son
The Last of the Old Gods
The Lay of Aotrou and Itroun
The Lay of the Children of Húrin
The Lay of the Fall of Gondolin
The Lion Is Loud and Proud
The Little House of Lost Play: Mar Vanwa Tyaliéva
The Man in the Moon Came Down Too Soon
The Man in the Moon Stayed Up Too Late
The Swallow, and the Traveller on the Plains
The wind was on the withered heath
The world was young, the mountains green,
Twenty years have flowed away down the long river
Under the mountain dark and tall
When winter first begins to bite
Where now the horse and the rider? Where is the horn that was blowing?
The Mermaid's Flute from 'The Lay of Earendel'
The Horns of the Host of Doriath
An Ode Inspired by Intimations of the Approach of Early Morning Tea
Ye laggard woodlands and ye slumbrous brakes
I stood upon an empty shore before the sun was born
A Rhyme Royal upon Easter Morning
Moonshine: Verses in a Medieval Measure
Lines Composed in a Village Inn on an Evening of Extraordinary Liquid Beauty
The Tale of Beewolf Son of Echgethew
Völsungakviða en nýja eða Sigurðarkviða en mesta
Guðrúnarkviða en nýja eða Dráp Niflunga
Hit was an olde mon fro Pimbilmere
When little Louis came to stay
Though all things fail & come to naught,
My heart is not in this land where I live:
'At last the time has come,' he said,

wikitext.*:
{{Poem infobox | title="In western lands beneath the Sun" | written=Between [[1938]] and [[1954]] | revised=Between 1938 and 1954 | published=''[[The Return of the King]]''
''[[The Road Goes Ever On (book)|The Road Goes Ever On]]''
''[[The Collected Poems of J.R.R. Tolkien]]'' | subject=[[Samwise Gamgee]] }} [[File:Matěj Čadil - In western lands.jpg|thumb|''In Western Lands beneath the Sun'' by [[Matěj Čadil]]]] '''In western lands beneath the Sun''', possibly written by [[Bilbo Baggins]], is a song sung by [[Sam Gamgee]] on [[14 March]] {{TA|3019}}{{App|Great}} in the [[Tower of Cirith Ungol]]. Sam had just climbed to the top of the stairs in the tower but could not find [[Frodo Baggins]]; he felt he was not actually at top of the tower but he was unable to discover any way that led upwards. Defeated, Sam bowed his head. Suddenly, to his surprise, he began to sing. At first he only recited childish tunes and rhymes, but then a new song arose in him: ==Poem excerpt== In western lands beneath the Sun the flowers may rise in Spring, the trees may bud, the waters run, the merry [[finches]] sing. Or there maybe 'tis cloudless night and swaying beeches bear the Elven-stars as jewels white amid their branching hair. Sam began to sing the line "Beyond all towers strong and high" again but stopped abruptly when he thought he could hear a faint answering voice. The voice stopped but then he heard the footsteps of [[Snaga (orc of Mordor)|Snaga]] approaching. Sam's voice, obviously not that of an [[Elves|Elf]], had attracted the [[Orcs|orc]], who came to shut Frodo up. Snaga brought in a ladder which enabled him to reach the final chamber above, soon to be followed by Sam.{{RK|VI1}} ==Portrayal in adaptations== Donald Swann wrote music for this song, which can be found in the book ''[[The Road Goes Ever On (book)|The Road Goes Ever On]]'';{{RGEO|Lands}} it is also found on the accompanying CD of the latest version. Stephen Oliver also wrote music for the song for the BBC Radio dramatisation. It was sung in the story by Bill Nighy (billed as William Nighy) and on the BBC Record by wine critic, Oz Clarke. In [[Paul Corfield Godfrey]]'s opera ''[[Beren and Lúthien, Op. 47 (Opera)|Beren and Lúthien]]'', this poem is given to the titular characters, with Lúthien singing the first stanza and Beren the second as she discovers him in [[Sauron]]'s lair.https://www.paulcorfieldgodfrey.co.uk/beren-and-luthien ==See also== * [[Poems in The Lord of the Rings|Poems in ''The Lord of the Rings'']] {{references}} {{poems}} [[Category:Poems in The Return of the King]] [[Category:Songs]]
